author: Maurizio Agliata

text:
This tune has some of the most distinctive elements from a Tim Follin trademark piece, except the prog rock thing present in other great pieces of him, but enhanced 100% in a full quality sound, almost realistic:
-Rock and techno dance mixing. You're literally listening a weird and catchy mixbag between rock and techno/disco, very enjoyable. Wanna dance, pogo or both? Ideal to both rock, prog or dance lovers.
-Sampled chords sequencing an element present in any of the tunes created for consoles with sampling, except for Sega Genesis (Time Trax), where he does that manually manipulating the waves to create one-channeled chords. Combining the chords sequences in such creative way, giving an epic effect to dance or incidental music. Eurodance did that and you can listen Richard Jacques in Sonic 3D Blast for Saturn doing something like that, but Follin did it better to me.
-Wall of soundchip Pushing the chip to give the best sound possible doing things that are uncommon to do even in a familiar console like Super Nintendo. That enhances the sound and the whole experience.
-Single rhythm, complex music Tim often does progtunes with rhythm changes but he was also very good doing tunes with single rhythm but too many musical details. Chord changes, different melodies, multiple sections, etc. You can't get bored. If this is accompanied by a catchy rhythm, you did it the impossible: Do a catchy tune with complex music. Only a true master.
author: Fuki Makai

text: I wasn't a big fan of this game (I'm sure some of you recognize that logo), but it had this particular track I've always been a big fan of. Back then I had no idea who composed it, but now years later I instantly recognize the Follin brothers' style. It has a lot of the same synths as Plok's soundtrack. Very high quality SNES sound as always with the Follins.
